ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TRANSFER OF TEACHERS
(Government policy)


    1. Mr L. P. Rodrigo asked the Minister for Education if he is aware that a considerable number of transfers of teachers are being made and some at an instant's notice through telephone calls from the Ministry; why these transfers are necessary and carried out in such manner; and if he will state his Ministry's policy on the transfer of teachers.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Minister to reply. In the first five months of this year 509 teachers, or only 2.6 per cent of the entire teaching force of 19,200 teachers, were transferred. Of this number, 352 transfers, or 70 per cent, were effected during the first two months as a result of transfers of pupils at the request of parents. Such transfers are unavoidable because my Ministry makes every effort to satisfy the wishes of parents in the choice of school for pupils who are entering primary or secondary school for the first time. Consequently, the number of classes authorised and the corresponding number of teachers assigned to each school at the end of the previous year have to be adjusted at the beginning of each school year. Moreover, the choice of a second language and the number and type of second language teachers needed for a particular school can only be ascertained when the pupils have settled down after the transfer exercise.

    Apart from these unavoidable transfers at the beginning of the year, there are other reasons which account for transfers on a small scale throughout the year. These include the secondment of teachers to other Ministries and statutory boards; adjustment in the staffing quota as a result of trainees qualified as trained teachers and, consequently, taking in a full teaching load; changes

Column: 447

in the curriculum resulting in different staffing needs; and requests from the teachers themselves.

    Transfers at an instant's notice by telephone calls are made only when the situation warrants such action, as when a vacancy is created by death or unexpected retirement, or when teachers are rendered redundant in one school while classes in another school are without teachers as a result of a mass transfer of pupils.

    The policy of my Ministry is to keep transfers of teachers down to a minimum consistent with the needs of the schools and the interest of the pupils. To minimise the number of transfers, my Ministry introduced a new scheme last year whereby primary teachers with at least five years' teaching experience could opt for a transfer to a school of their choice on the understanding that the Ministry would not transfer them out for the next five years, and the teachers themselves would not ask for a transfer during these five years unless the circumstances were altogether exceptional.

    Of the 257 teachers who applied, 200 were accepted under this five-year no transfer scheme. However, with the greater emphasis on technical and vocational education, the consequential transfer of students from the academic to the technical stream and the proposed conversion of vocational schools into industrial training centres, more transfers of teachers in the next two or three years will be inevitable.

Column: 447

SCHOOL PRINCIPALS
(Duties)


    2. Mr L. P. Rodrigo asked the Minister for Education (a) if he is aware that during the first five months of this year heads of schools have already been required to submit an unduly large number of returns to the Ministry; and why such a considerable number of returns have been called for; (b) whether he is also aware that certain heads of schools have been put in charge of

Column: 448

defined areas and have been required to telephone all the schools in the area to secure any data for the Ministry as and when the Ministry calls for such data by telephone; and why such a system is necessary; and (c) whether an efficient system of data registration and maintenance can be devised so as to allow more time for heads of schools to devote their attention to improving the quality of teaching in their schools.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by my Minister to reply. During the first five months of this year, schools were requested to submit a total of 82 returns. This cannot by any stretch of the imagination be regarded as an unduly large number in view of the fact that my Ministry administers 593 schools with 19,160 teachers, 2,550 non-teaching staff and 530,000 students. The majority of the returns are of an annual recurrent nature, such as those relating to staff and student data for the purpose of compiling the Ministry's statistical bulletins, nominal rolls for the four streams for 15 school examinations at different levels - the Primary School Leaving Examination, the School Certificate, the Higher School Certificate, the Secondary Vocational School Certificate, the National Language Certificate examinations; returns in respect of bursaries, scholarships and training awards; and returns seeking the schools' proposals for special or recurrent expenditure for the preparation of the next year's budget estimates. Other circulars seeking information on an ad hoc basis are sent to schools only when strictly necessary. In all cases, information is sought from schools only when such information cannot be obtained from any other source.

    With regard to the second part of the question, Sir, a system of relaying urgent messages or instructions to schools by telephone was first introduced during confrontation. Under this system, my Ministry would telephone a number of designated schools which would in turn relay the message to schools in their area. The aim of this system was to get the message through to all the schools

Column: 449

as quickly as possible and to avoid overloading a few telephone lines. Now that confrontation is over and security is no longer a major problem, the system of relaying messages by telephone is only resorted to in emergencies, such as the evacuation of students when schools in certain areas are flooded.

    In answer to the last part of the question, Sir, an efficient system of data registration and maintenance is being devised. All teachers have completed a pro forma in which their personal particulars, details of qualifications, teaching experience, service matters, extracurricular activities, community service, in-service courses attended, etc, are entered. These returns are currently being processed for computer programming so that essential information may be made available at short notice for the purpose of educational planning, and it is expected that the frequency of having to submit returns of this nature will diminish.

    Mr L. P. Rodrigo (Serangoon Gardens): Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education state that as and when this system of registration of data is set up, the number of returns that are sent out to the schools will be minimised?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: if we consider the types of returns we look for, by and large, the largest number of returns sent out related to examination divisions, of which no less than 31 were sent out during the first half of this year. These are unlikely to diminish because we still have to know who will be taking what examinations. But others of a recurrent nature pertaining to personal data will be minimised in the future.

Column: 449

TEACHERS' COMPLAINTS
AGAINST PRINCIPALS


    3. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Education whether complaints made by teachers against their principals are investigated; and what action is taken against the teachers concerned if, on investigation, the

Column: 450

complaints are found to be unfounded and unfair.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by my Minister to reply. Complaints made by teachers against principals are investigated. Disciplinary action would be taken against the teachers concerned if such complaints, after investigation, are found to be malicious. There are, however, not many known cases of teachers complaining openly against their principals. This may be due to the fact that correspondence between teachers and the Ministry is conducted through the principal.

    Since January 1967 there have been four such cases. In one case, the principal was dismissed. In the second, the allegation was unfounded but as the complainants were anonymous, no further action could be taken. In the third case, some of the allegations were partly true and the principal was sent for and advised. In the fourth case, the allegation was unsubstantiated and the teacher, a temporary officer, was reprimanded. He has since left the service.

Column: 450

TEACHERS OF ENGLISH IN CHINESE SCHOOLS


    4. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Education if he is aware (a) that some Cambridge School Certificate holders teach English not only in secondary classes but also in Pre-University classes in Chinese schools; and (b) that some English teachers regard posting to Chinese schools as a drudgery and try their best to be transferred away; and what steps he proposes to take in the matter.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by my Minister to reply. It is true that some of the teachers teaching English in Pre-University classes in Chinese secondary schools possess only the School Certificate qualification. However, this situation has

Column: 451

to be viewed in the light of the following factors:

    (1) The standard of English in the non-English medium school is generally pitched at a level two years below that of a corresponding class in the English school. That is to say, Pre-University I students in non-English schools are doing Secondary III English.

    (2) Since 1965 special in-service courses in the teaching of English as a second language have been conducted for teachers of English in non-English schools. Of the 1,292 English teachers in Chinese schools, 794 have successfully completed the course and another 402 are currently undergoing training.

    (3) Of the 212 teachers of English currently teaching in 21 Chinese secondary schools with Pre-University classes, 26 are graduates; five have had special training abroad in the teaching of English as a second language, and 14 possess the Higher School Certificate. As and when more graduates are available, they will be posted to Chinese secondary schools to teach English in the Pre-University classes.

    In answer to the second part of the question, Sir, some teachers of English in Chinese schools prefer to be posted back to English schools for three main reasons:

    (1) Being used to the environment of an English school, they find it difficult to adapt them selves to the situation in a Chinese school where the main language of instruction and school administration is Chinese.

    (2) As teachers of English, they teach no other subjects.

Column: 452



    Consequently, they find their work somewhat monotonous and the amount of corrections excessive.

    (3) Very often teachers of English are called upon to help with translations and other chores because of their fluency in English.

    My Ministry has taken steps to ascertain the number of such teachers who wish to be transferred back to English schools. At the same time, a circular has been issued inviting applicants from English-medium teachers who are genuinely interested in teaching English as a second language. Those who apply will be given special training in the teaching of English as a second language and posted to Chinese schools as replacements for those who opt to be posted back to English schools. The question of monotony and excessive work will also be ameliorated when science and technical subjects are taught in the English medium in the next few years.

Column: 452

JOO CHIAT
(Flushing of drains)


    5. Mr Yeoh Ghim Seng asked the Minister for Health if he will inform the House of the measures his Ministry has taken or proposes to take to ensure the adequate flushing of all drains, including outlet drains, in the Joo Chiat Constituency, as choked drains and stagnant waters are not conducive to the health of the residents in the area.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, where there are regular obstructions to the flow of water in drains due to refuse being thoughtlessly thrown into them causing stagnation of water, smell, and the breeding of flies and mosquitoes, especially where such drains are small and narrow, structurally defective, or are covered by slabs or hawkers' paraphernalia, thus actually hindering and physically preventing the proper cleansing of and the removal of refuse from such drains, then, as a public

Column: 453

health measure, the flushing of such drains is carried out.

    The flushing of a drain so as to remove obstruction caused by refuse and to provide some measure of flow of water through it, is, therefore, only a temporary palliative measure which is resorted to only when there is no access or there are obstructions over the drain preventing physical entry into the drain for cleansing work. Accordingly, the small drains around congested hawker areas in Joo Chiat and Katong are flushed every day, while in some less congested shop-houses and residential areas, flushing of the drains once or twice a week is carried out.

    Storm water drains receiving no sullage water do not require any flushing, while in big outlet drains, flushing is not effective, as the small jets of water from the flushing hoses cannot move the refuse in big drains, let alone dislodge obstructions in them. This is because the combined inertia of the great volume of water and the big mass of refuse in such big outlet drains rapidly dissipates the energy of the small water jets of the flushing hoses.

    It is estimated that only about 10 per cent of all drains in built-up areas in Singapore are being flushed as proper cleansing work cannot be done because of obstructions or hindrances on or over these drains, using about 350,000 gallons of water per day. If all drains, including outlet drains, in Singapore were to he flushed, as suggested by the hon. Member for Joo Chiat, this would require at least 3.5 million gallons of water every day going down the drain. This would cost the Government $3,500 in water bills per day; an expenditure which is not only unnecessary, but completely unjustifiable as the precious water in our island republic should never be allowed to be wasted in this way.

    The flushing of drains, accordingly, is not the answer. The solution, therefore, is not to allow drains to be choked with ref use, thrown indiscriminately and thoughtlessly by hawkers, shopkeepers and householders alike. Refuse should he placed in properly covered dust-bins for

Column: 454

removal by public cleansing workmen. Drains should not be slabbed and covered over so that there will be no obstructions or hindrances to public cleansing workers cleaning and removing refuse from drains.

    Under the new Conservancy Regulations which came into force on 1st July, 1968 - I hope hon. Members are quite familiar with the provisions - every householder, hawker and stall-holder will be required to have a dustbin or be provided with a dustbin by the Cleansing Department, and the cost recovered from them through the P.U.B. Consolidated Accounts. Heavy fines of up to $150 for the first offence, $500 for the second offence, and $1,000 for the third and subsequent offences will be imposed on anyone depositing refuse on to the roadsides, backlanes, vacant grounds, or into drains. With these revised public health regulations, there should be very little need for drain flushing, and there should be a new consciousness among the public cleansing workers and the members of the public alike to make and keep Singapore the cleanest city in Southeast Asia.

Column: 454

DUST-BINS IN PUBLIC PLACES
(Increased provision)


    6. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Health whether he will consider increasing the number of dust-bins provided in public places and placing them at closer intervals as a means to reduce indiscriminate throwing of litter.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, the indiscriminate throwing of refuse and littering are usually the result of a lack of civic pride or a sense of civic consciousness. However, it has been realised that an insufficiency of suitable refuse bins or containers may be a contributory factor to such indiscriminate littering. Accordingly, in 1967 the Public Health Division took steps to design and to provide a large number of proper litter bins so as to reduce the tendency among the public to throw refuse about indiscriminately. Due to the large numbers of such litter

Column: 455

bins that must be bought and fixed, the provision of such litter bins is being done in phases.

    It was decided to give priority to the fixing of litter bins at bus stops. The fixing of such litter bins to all the bus stops in the city area has been completed, and similarly all bus stops in the main thoroughfares in the rural areas have also been provided with such litter bins.

    At the moment, the next phase of the operation is under way, in which litter bins are being fixed at road junctions and along busy streets especially in the shopping areas and near and around cinemas and picture halls. To date, a total of 1,660 litter bins have been installed in such places.

    Being aware that a lot of littering is taking place in areas where hawkers congregate, hawkers are now required to provide refuse bins; collection bins for such refuse exist at all authorised hawker congregations. In the city area, 63 congested hawker sites have been so provided and 300 refuse bins are now in use.

    This year, the Public Health Division has placed orders for another 2,000 litter bins which will be fixed at closer intervals along all busy streets and shopping areas. But it is to be appreciated that while the Government can provide refuse bins and litter bins, the provision of such facilities alone would not prevent littering if the public were not to make use of them, in order that Singapore can be the cleanest city in South-east Asia, such indiscriminate throwing of litter should he actively discouraged, and more effective use would have to be made of the litter bins that have been provided by the Public Health Division.

Column: 455

DUMPING GROUND FOR BULK
REFUSE FOR JURONG
INDUSTRIAL ESTATE


    7. Mr Low Guan Onn asked the Minister for Health if a dumping ground

Column: 456

for bulk refuse can be provided near to the Jurong Industrial Estate, as great expense is at present being caused to Jurong factory owners on haulage of bulk refuse to the nearest dumping ground at Tampines which is about 25 miles from Jurong Town, and as more and more industries are being established in the Estate.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the need for the sanitary disposal of both domestic refuse and trade waste from the Jurong New Town and the Jurong Industrial Estate has been envisaged in the health planning requirements of the Ministry of Health.

    It is realised that the long haulage for disposal at the Tampines Dumping Ground for refuse collected in the Jurong Industrial Estate has caused inconvenience and extra expense to the Jurong factory owners. The problem of distance has been aggravated by the closure of the former dumping ground at Clementi Road in 1966 by an important Government development near this Clementi Road site. Planning approval has already been obtained from the Planning Department for the development of a refuse dumping ground, conveniently located for the Jurong Industrial Estate, off 16 ms. Chua Chu Kang Road. Necessary steps for revoking the temporary occupation licences of this site and for the re-settlement of persons affected are being taken by the Commissioner of Lands.

    Development of supporting facilities at the dumping ground is being processed. Among these is the provision of a bulldozer, for which approval for the purchase has only just been approved by the Ministry of Finance. Complementary facilities like a site office and stores are also required. The provision of a vehicle weighbridge for the purpose of work control will be included in the development of this site. It is expected that before the end of the year this new dumping ground will be in operation.

SINGAPORE STOCK EXCHANGE
(Legislation to set up independent commission to supervise operation)


    9. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Finance if he will consider introducing legislation to set up an independent commission to supervise the operation of the Singapore Stock Exchange.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by my Minister to reply to this question and also to questions Nos. 10 to 13 inclusive appearing in the Order Paper today.

    The answer to this question is no. The Government is prepared to allow the Stock Exchange of Malaysia and Singapore to continue to function as a self-regulating body in co-operation with the Ministry of Finance. Agreement has been reached between the Committee of the Stock Exchange and officials of my Ministry on the procedure to be followed by the Committee when considering applications for admission to the Official List in respect of Singapore registered companies.

    For instance, in the case of a new floatation or the sale to the public of existing shares, it will no longer be sufficient to file with the Registrar of Companies a prospectus which meets the minimum requirements of the Companies Act. The promoters will in

Column: 459

future be required to make a detailed disclosure of all material facts.

    The Government is alive to the important role the Stock Exchange can play in fostering the development of a strong capital market in Singapore. The Stock Exchange will fail in this purpose unless it maintains high ethical standards and exercises sound judgment. Only then will it command the confidence of the investing public. At present, a good investment proposal will be readily over-subscribed. But if standards are relaxed and unsound ventures are foisted upon the public, this readiness to subscribe to new issues will no longer prevail. It has happened to the Stock Exchange of some developing countries. It must not be allowed to happen here.

    So long as the existing arrangements for co-operation between the Stock Exchange and my Ministry work satisfactorily and help to maintain high ethical standards, the Government does not propose to set up any formal machinery for regulating the Stock Exchange, especially since the Exchange is still quite small.

TOURISM POTENTIAL OF BALI


    10. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Finance if he will make a statement on the progress made by the technical fact-finding mission to Indonesia on the tourism potential of Bali.

    Mr Tang See Chim (for the Minister for Finance): The technical mission returned to Singapore on 8th May, 1968, and its members are preparing a report for submission to the Governments of Indonesia and Singapore. The report is now in the course of being printed and will soon be laid before Parliament.

    All I can say at this stage is that the prospects of successful development of Bali as an international tourist centre are much better than had previously been thought possible. The preparation of the runway to cope with international jet airliners is in an advanced stage. Another welcome factor is the willingness of the Indonesian Government to

Column: 460

offer favourable terms to foreign investment in hotels. But, most of all, we are encouraged by the high quality of Indonesian engineers and architects now planning the Bali project. Professional members of the Singapore mission were impressed by their qualifications, experience and dedication.

    There are, however, a number of problems to be solved and no doubt the report will go into these at some length. This project offers much scope for co-operation between the Governments of Indonesia and Singapore within the framework of ASEAN.

TOURIST PROMOTION BOARD
(Measures to eliminate fleecing of tourists)


    11. Mr Yeoh Ghim Seng asked the Minister for Finance whether he is aware of any measures now being taken or proposed to be taken by the Tourist Promotion Board to eliminate any possible fleecing of tourists by unscrupulous taxi-drivers, shop-keepers, etc.; and whether he will inform the House of such measures.

    Mr Tang See Chim (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, through the combined efforts of the Tourist Promotion Board, the relevant Government departments, the taxi-drivers' associations, the bus operators and the Singapore Tourist Association, many of the evils which beset the tourist industry in the past have been corrected to some extent.
